greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of 2*Pi/5.
comment: Also, with proper offset, decimal expansion of the magnetic permeability of vacuum in SI units, mu_0 = 4*Pi*10^-7 N A^-2, an assigned metrological constant. [This exact expression for mu_0 was valid until the 2019 SI redefinition. In the New SI, mu_0 is numerically very close to that value but is determined only up to a certain error. - _Andrey Zabolotskiy_, May 22 2019]
Regarding these, see A003678 for general context notes, references and links. - _Stanislav Sykora_, Jun 16 2012

Iff n is +- 1, 2, 3, 4 or 6, then 2*cos(2*Pi/n) is an integer. This formula plays a role in the short proof of the Crystallographic Restriction Theorem (see A217290). For n = 5, 2*cos(2*Pi/5) = 1/Golden Ratio = 0.6180339887..., associated with quasicrystals and 5-fold rotational symmetry. - _Raphie Frank_, Dec 21 2012

With offset 2 this is also the decimal expansion of 4*Pi, the surface area of a sphere whose diameter equals the square root of 4, hence its radius is 1. More generally x*Pi is also the surface area of a sphere whose diameter equals the square root of x. - _Omar E. Pol_, Jan 18 2013, Oct 05 2013, Dec 22 2013
link: Ivan Panchenko, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
mathematica: RealDigits[ 2*Pi/5, 10, 111][[1]] (* _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Dec 02 2009 and modified by _Robert G. Wilson v_ *)
